citations.narrative:
Several enclosures contained excessive amounts of feces, soiled litter and needed cleaning. The following animals were
impacted: 2 wallaby, 2 cavy, 2 capy, 2 coati, 2 kinkajous,3 african crested porcupines, 2 sheep, 2 zebu.
The enclosure housing 1 capy and 1 cavy also had a heavily soiled area surrounding the drinking water bowl. The
animals had to walk through soiled standing water and feces to get to the water bowl.
Enclosures with unsanitary conditions and excessive amounts of feces put the animals at risk of increased disease
exposure due to contact with feces and soiled materials.
The regulations state that excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent
contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
Correct by 28Feb2024

The facility has multiple areas that contain piles of unused equipment, feeders, waterers, cages, and trash/trash bags.
The facility in general is cluttered and unkempt.
Not providing adequate trash disposal and not conducting adequate facility cleaning, maintenance and upkeep allows
disease-transmitting pests to prosper and presents a cluttered, unkempt image to the public.
The regulations state that premises (building and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash
shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
Correct by 28February2024

The facility has one full time employee and one half-time employee tasked with managing the husbandry of the animal
park. Based on the lack of adequate sanitation for many of the 41 mammals (of 185 total animals) housed at this facility,
as observed during this inspection, coupled with the additional citations made in this inspection report, the facility has
insufficient manpower to maintain the required level of sanitation per the regulations.
Not having enough employees present to maintain appropriate levels of sanitation puts the animals at increased risk of
disease due to unsanitary conditions.
The regulations state that a sufficient number of adequately trained employees shall be utilized to maintain the
professionally acceptable level of husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Such practices shall be under a supervisor
who has a background in animal care.
Correct by 28Feb2024.

The waterfowl in the bird portion of the barnyard area do not have an adequate pool that allows them to conduct normal
waterfowl behaviors, including swimming, submarining, and foraging. When the empty pool was filled at the inspector’s
request, all 7 geese tried to get into this small pool, which resulted in squabbles among them. They also prevented the
ducks from entering the pool while under observation. There are 7 geese and 10 ducks and the pool that is provided
measures approximately 2’ x 4’ with a 12” depth.
Not providing adequate pool areas for waterfowl can impact their wellbeing and ability to maintain appropriate health
levels.
Special space requirements for wading and aquatic birds. Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must
contain a pool or other aquatic area (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water features) and a dry area that
allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient
surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing,
swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by
other birds in the enclosure.
Correct by 28February2024.

The portion of the barnyard area containing 9 ducks, 4 peafowl, 7 geese and 2 emu had no water available for the birds.
Both the pool and the two water buckets were empty. When the buckets and pool were being filled at the inspector’s
request, the ducks rushed to the buckets and drank voraciously. One Pekin duck was observed to drink for almost 8
minutes. When the inspector and employee backed away, the geese and peafowl quickly approached and drank eagerly.
Not providing adequate water for drinking for birds can result in serious harm to their health and wellbeing.
The regulations state that potable water must be provided in sufficient quantity to every bird housed at the facility., unless
restricted by the attending veterinarian. If potable water is not continually available to the birds, it must be offered to them
as often as necessary to ensure their health and well-being. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized in
accordance with § 3.158 as often as necessary to keep them clean and free of contamination. Used water receptacles
must be cleaned and sanitized before they may be used to provide water to birds maintained in a separate enclosure.
Group-housed birds must have multiple water receptacles where needed to ensure that all birds have access to sufficient
water.
Corrected during inspection.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Multiple bird enclosures contained excessive amounts of fecal build-up, unclean feeders, unclean waterers, unclean
flooring, and/or feather build-up. The birds impacted included 10 ducks, 20 chickens, 5 turkeys, 3 umbrella cockatoos, 4
peafowl, and 12 macaws.
Unsanitary conditions for birds can lead to increased risks to their health and wellbeing.
The regulations state that primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for birds must be sanitized as often as
necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards
Correct by 28Feb2024

The facility has one full time employee and one half-time employee tasked with managing the husbandry of the animal
park. Based on the lack of adequate sanitation for many of the 144 birds (of 185 total animals in park) housed at this
facility, as observed during this inspection, coupled with the additional citations made in this inspection report, the facility
has insufficient manpower to maintain the required level of sanitation per the regulations.
Not having adequate staff to complete the required routine cleaning and husbandry tasks puts the animals at increased
risk of disease.
The regulations state that a sufficient number of adequately trained employees or attendants must be utilized to maintain
the professionally acceptable level of husbandry and handling practices set forth in this subpart. Such practices must be
conducted under the supervision of a bird caretaker who has appropriate experience in the husbandry and care of birds
that are being managed in a given setting.
Correct by 28February2024

A golden pheasant was found injured, scalped and deceased in its enclosure on 30January2024. The enclosure also
contained 2 ringneck pheasants, 3 budgerigars, 1 galah cockatoo, 1 yellow-crested cockatoo, 2 cockatiels, 1 Goffins
cockatoo, 1 coconut lorikeet, and 1 rose-ringed parakeet. All birds other than the deceased pheasant were observed to be
in good condition. The facility had observed no inter-bird aggression before the pheasant was aggressively attacked,
resulting in its death.
Having mixed species in the same enclosure without close monitoring can lead to interspecies aggression which can
result in injury and death of the inhabitants.
Birds may not be housed with other animals, including members of their own species, unless they are compatible, do not
prevent access to food, water, or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-
being of each other. Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and
by actual observations to ensure that the birds are, in fact, compatible.
Corrected prior to inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Beau Phillips, Investigator
Additional Inspectors:
Chris Caudle, Investigator n

narrative:
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
Several enclosures contained excessive amounts of feces, soiled litter and needed cleaning. The following animals were 
impacted: 2 wallaby, 2 cavy, 2 capy, 2 coati, 2 kinkajous,3 african crested porcupines, 2 sheep, 2 zebu.  
 
The enclosure housing 1 capy and 1 cavy also had a heavily soiled area surrounding the drinking water bowl. The 
animals had to walk through soiled standing water and feces to get to the water bowl.  
 
Enclosures with unsanitary conditions and excessive amounts of feces put the animals at risk of increased disease 
exposure due to contact with feces and soiled materials.  
 
The regulations state that excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent 
contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. 
 
Correct by 28Feb2024 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility has multiple areas that contain piles of unused equipment, feeders, waterers, cages, and trash/trash bags. 
The facility in general is cluttered and unkempt.  
 
Not providing adequate trash disposal and not conducting adequate facility cleaning, maintenance and upkeep allows 
disease-transmitting pests to prosper and presents a cluttered, unkempt image to the public.  
 
The regulations state that premises (building and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the 
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash 
shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.  
 
Correct by 28February2024

3.132 
   
Employees. 
The facility has one full time employee and one half-time employee tasked with managing the husbandry of the animal 
park. Based on the lack of adequate sanitation for many of the 41 mammals (of 185 total animals) housed at this facility, 
as observed during this inspection, coupled with the additional citations made in this inspection report, the facility has 
insufficient manpower to maintain the required level of sanitation per the regulations.  
 
Not having enough employees present to maintain appropriate levels of sanitation puts the animals at increased risk of 
disease due to unsanitary conditions.  
 
The regulations state that a sufficient number of adequately trained employees shall be utilized to maintain the 
professionally acceptable level of husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Such practices shall be under a supervisor 
who has a background in animal care.  
 
Correct by 28Feb2024. 
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The waterfowl in the bird portion of the barnyard area do not have an adequate pool that allows them to conduct normal 
waterfowl behaviors, including swimming, submarining, and foraging. When the empty pool was filled at the inspector’s 
request, all 7 geese tried to get into this small pool, which resulted in squabbles among them. They also prevented the 
ducks from entering the pool while under observation. There are 7 geese and 10 ducks and the pool that is provided 
measures approximately 2’ x 4’ with a 12” depth.  
 
Not providing adequate pool areas for waterfowl can impact their wellbeing and ability to maintain appropriate health 
levels.  
 
Special space requirements for wading and aquatic birds. Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must 
contain a pool or other aquatic area (e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water features) and a dry area that 
allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient 
surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, 
swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by 
other birds in the enclosure. 
 
Correct by 28February2024. 
3.156  Direct
   
Watering 
The portion of the barnyard area containing 9 ducks, 4 peafowl, 7 geese and 2 emu had no water available for the birds. 
Both the pool and the two water buckets were empty. When the buckets and pool were being filled at the inspector’s

request, the ducks rushed to the buckets and drank voraciously. One Pekin duck was observed to drink for almost 8 
minutes. When the inspector and employee backed away, the geese and peafowl quickly approached and drank eagerly.  
 
Not providing adequate water for drinking for birds can result in serious harm to their health and wellbeing. 
 
The regulations state that potable water must be provided in sufficient quantity to every bird housed at the facility., unless 
restricted by the attending veterinarian. If potable water is not continually available to the birds, it must be offered to them 
as often as necessary to ensure their health and well-being. Water receptacles must be kept clean and sanitized in 
accordance with § 3.158 as often as necessary to keep them clean and free of contamination. Used water receptacles 
must be cleaned and sanitized before they may be used to provide water to birds maintained in a separate enclosure. 
Group-housed birds must have multiple water receptacles where needed to ensure that all birds have access to sufficient 
water.  
 
Corrected during inspection. 
3.158(b)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Multiple bird enclosures contained excessive amounts of fecal build-up, unclean feeders, unclean waterers, unclean 
flooring, and/or feather build-up. The birds impacted included 10 ducks, 20 chickens, 5 turkeys, 3 umbrella cockatoos, 4 
peafowl, and 12 macaws.  
 
Unsanitary conditions for birds can lead to increased risks to their health and wellbeing. 
 
The regulations state that primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for birds must be sanitized as often as 
necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards 
 
Correct by 28Feb2024 
3.159 
   
Employees 
The facility has one full time employee and one half-time employee tasked with managing the husbandry of the animal 
park. Based on the lack of adequate sanitation for many of the 144 birds (of 185 total animals in park) housed at this 
facility, as observed during this inspection, coupled with the additional citations made in this inspection report, the facility 
has insufficient manpower to maintain the required level of sanitation per the regulations.  
 
Not having adequate staff to complete the required routine cleaning and husbandry tasks puts the animals at increased 
risk of disease.  
 
The regulations state that a sufficient number of adequately trained employees or attendants must be utilized to maintain 
the professionally acceptable level of husbandry and handling practices set forth in this subpart. Such practices must be 
conducted under the supervision of a bird caretaker who has appropriate experience in the husbandry and care of birds

that are being managed in a given setting. 
 
 Correct by 28February2024 
3.160(b)  Critical
   
Compatibility and separation 
A golden pheasant was found injured, scalped and deceased in its enclosure on 30January2024. The enclosure also 
contained 2 ringneck pheasants, 3 budgerigars, 1 galah cockatoo, 1 yellow-crested cockatoo, 2 cockatiels, 1 Goffins 
cockatoo, 1 coconut lorikeet, and 1 rose-ringed parakeet. All birds other than the deceased pheasant were observed to be 
in good condition. The facility had observed no inter-bird aggression before the pheasant was aggressively attacked, 
resulting in its death.  
 
Having mixed species in the same enclosure without close monitoring can lead to interspecies aggression which can 
result in injury and death of the inhabitants.  
Birds may not be housed with other animals, including members of their own species, unless they are compatible, do not 
prevent access to food, water, or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and well-
being of each other. Compatibility must be determined in accordance with generally accepted professional practices and 
by actual observations to ensure that the birds are, in fact, compatible.  
 
Corrected prior to inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors:  
 
Beau Phillips, Investigator 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Chris Caudle, Investigator n
